model_response: Sure. The phases of a clinical trial can be classified as either interventional or observational. An interventional study involves the administration of an intervention to the subjects, while an observational study involves simply observing the subjects. In your case, since you plan to use three diagnostic tests, it makes sense to conduct an observational study to compare the accuracy of the tests.

For a Phase II study, you should include patients who are at high risk for the condition under investigation. For this study, that would be patients with suspected coronary artery stenosis. Exclusion criteria would include patients with contraindications to the use of the diagnostic tests, such as severe claustrophobia or a history of severe allergic reactions to contrast dye.

For participant exclusion, you should exclude individuals with a history of coronary artery bypass grafting, percutaneous coronary intervention, or any other revascularization procedure within the past 6 months. Additionally, individuals with a history of allergy to contrast media or iodinated contrast dye should be excluded.
For the study arms, you could have a control arm with only visual assessment and an intervention arm with FFR and IVUS.

The second arm should be the novel diagnostic test, ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR), as the intervention/treatment. The comparison group for this arm should be coronary angiography, as it is the current standard of care for evaluating coronary artery stenosis.
